title: How to Print Photographs in the Sun Using the Classic Cyanotype Process

steps.headline: Choose a formula.
steps.description:
This recipe makes approximately 50 8x10 inch prints. The cyanotype is made up of two simple solutions:
Solution A: 25 grams (0.88 oz) Ferric ammonium citrate (green) and 100 ml. water. Solution B: 10 grams (0.35 oz) Potassium ferricyanide and 100 ml. water.

steps.headline: Mix the chemicals.
Prepare the canvas.
Printing the cyanotype.
Processing and drying.
steps.description:
When the print has been exposed, process your print by rinsing it in cold water. The wash also removes any unexposed chemicals. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c8/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-5Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c8/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-5Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Wash for at least 5 minutes, until all chemicals are removed and the water runs clear. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cb/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-5Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-5Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cb/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-5Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-5Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Oxidation is also hastened this way - bringing out the blue color. The final print can now be hung to dry and be admired.

tyn: Art paper or fabric for coating
Glass or a contact print frame
Sunshine or a UV light source
text:
Choose a formula. This recipe makes approximately 50 8x10 inch prints. The cyanotype is made up of two simple solutions: Solution A: 25 grams (0.88 oz) Ferric ammonium citrate (green) and 100 ml. water. Solution B: 10 grams (0.35 oz) Potassium ferricyanide and 100 ml. water. Mix the chemicals. The cyanotype is made up of two simple solutions. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/50/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/50/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Potassium ferricyanide and Ferric ammonium citrate (green) are mixed with water separately. The two solutions are then blended together in equal parts. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/be/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/be/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Dissolve the chemicals in water to make two separate solutions. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/02/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet3.jpg/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/02/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet3.jpg/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Add Ammonium ferric citrate to water into one container and Potassium ferricyanide to water in another. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8c/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet4.jpg/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet4.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8c/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet4.jpg/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet4.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Stir with a plastic spoon until the chemicals dissolve. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1c/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet5.jpg/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet5.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1c/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet5.jpg/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet5.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Mix equal quantities of each solution together in a third container. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2b/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet6.jpg/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet6.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2b/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet6.jpg/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet6.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Unused solutions can be stored separately in brown bottles away from light, but will not last very long once they have been mixed. Dispose of any unused chemicals in a sensible and environmentally friendly way! {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/46/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet7.jpg/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet7.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/46/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet7.jpg/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet7.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Prepare the canvas. Using a brush, simply paint the chemicals onto the material. Paper, card, textiles or any natural material can be used to print on. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dc/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-3Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dc/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-3Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Decide how big your print is going to be, and cut your material to size. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/53/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-3Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-3Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/53/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-3Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-3Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Make sure your working area is dimly lit, or lit with a low-level tungsten bulb. Once the material is coated, leave it to dry in the dark. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c7/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-3Bullet3.jpg/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-3Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c7/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-3Bullet3.jpg/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-3Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Printing the cyanotype. Print a cyanotype by placing your negative (to reproduce a photograph) or object (to make a photogram) in contact with your coated paper or fabric. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2a/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-4Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2a/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-4Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Sandwich it with a piece of glass. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/06/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-4Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/06/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-4Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Expose the sandwich to UV light. Natural sunlight is the traditional light source, but UV lamps can also be used. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/38/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-4Bullet3.jpg/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-4Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/38/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-4Bullet3.jpg/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-4Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} A photogram can also be made by placing items on the surface. Plants, decorative items or other objects can be used to create silhouettes or interesting shapes. Exposure times can vary from a few minutes to several hours, depending on how strong your light source is or the season where you are printing. Processing and drying. When the print has been exposed, process your print by rinsing it in cold water. The wash also removes any unexposed chemicals. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c8/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-5Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c8/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-5Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Wash for at least 5 minutes, until all chemicals are removed and the water runs clear. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cb/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-5Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-5Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cb/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-5Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-5Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Oxidation is also hastened this way - bringing out the blue color. The final print can now be hung to dry and be admired.
sentences: Choose a formula.
This recipe makes approximately 50 8x10 inch prints.

The cyanotype is made up of two simple solutions:
Solution A: 25 grams (0.88 oz) Ferric ammonium citrate (green) and 100 ml.
water.
Solution B: 10 grams (0.35 oz) Potassium ferricyanide and 100 ml.
water.
Mix the chemicals.
The cyanotype is made up of two simple solutions.
The two solutions are then blended together in equal parts.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/be\/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/be\/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet2.jpg\/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Dissolve the chemicals in water to make two separate solutions.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/02\/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet3.jpg\/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/02\/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet3.jpg\/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Add Ammonium ferric citrate to water into one container and Potassium ferricyanide to water in another.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/8c\/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet4.jpg\/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet4.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/8c\/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet4.jpg\/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet4.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Stir with a plastic spoon until the chemicals dissolve.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/1c\/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet5.jpg\/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet5.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/1c\/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet5.jpg\/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet5.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Mix equal quantities of each solution together in a third container.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2b\/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet6.jpg\/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet6.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2b\/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet6.jpg\/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet6.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Unused solutions can be stored separately in brown bottles away from light, but will not last very long once they have been mixed.
Dispose of any unused chemicals in a sensible and environmentally friendly way!

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/46\/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet7.jpg\/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet7.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/46\/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet7.jpg\/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-2Bullet7.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Prepare the canvas.
Using a brush, simply paint the chemicals onto the material.
Paper, card, textiles or any natural material can be used to print on.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/dc\/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/d\/dc\/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Decide how big your print is going to be, and cut your material to size.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/53\/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-3Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-3Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/53\/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-3Bullet2.jpg\/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-3Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Make sure your working area is dimly lit, or lit with a low-level tungsten bulb.
Once the material is coated, leave it to dry in the dark.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c7\/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-3Bullet3.jpg\/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-3Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c7\/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-3Bullet3.jpg\/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-3Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Printing the cyanotype.
Print a cyanotype by placing your negative (to reproduce a photograph) or object (to make a photogram) in contact with your coated paper or fabric.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2a\/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2a\/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Sandwich it with a piece of glass.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/06\/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-4Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/06\/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-4Bullet2.jpg\/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Expose the sandwich to UV light.
Natural sunlight is the traditional light source, but UV lamps can also be used.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/38\/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-4Bullet3.jpg\/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-4Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/38\/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-4Bullet3.jpg\/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-4Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} A photogram can also be made by placing items on the surface.
Plants, decorative items or other objects can be used to create silhouettes or interesting shapes.
Exposure times can vary from a few minutes to several hours, depending on how strong your light source is or the season where you are printing.
Processing and drying.
When the print has been exposed, process your print by rinsing it in cold water.
The wash also removes any unexposed chemicals.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c8\/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c8\/Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Print-Photographs-in-the-Sun-Using-the-Classic-Cyanotype-Process-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Wash for at least 5 minutes, until all chemicals are removed and the water runs clear.
